text: thank you for the introduction so as james mentioned my name is griffin dietz and in my work i integrate perspectives
from hci cognitive development education and ai to design and develop cognitively
appropriate computing education platforms for young learners so in recent years we've seen a global
push for computing education for all children for whom this early exposure can lead to increased interest in the
field the development of computational thinking and literacy skills and computing readiness to support an entire
educational career and with growing influence and prevalence of ai and machine learning in
everyday life we see both new opportunities for delivering educational content that leverages ai
and new obligations to educate young learners about this kind of technology that they interact with every day
continue to do so more and more but there remains a lack of ai supported
computing education tools a number of computing education tools do exist but many students still lack
access because those tools don't meet the cognitive needs of the learners for example surrounding literacy or
problem solving skills these tools run on expensive specialized hardware
that families or school districts are unable to afford the tools are ineffective without
educator support or the tools cover out-of-date content compared to the state of the art and
computing i believe that we can address these gaps in access by taking an interdisciplinary
approach to the design and development of computing education platforms by first studying the developmental
capacities of young learners to engage with this content and then designing and developing
appropriate tools that directly address these findings we can build software systems to support accessible computing
education specifically today i'll argue that cognitively appropriate and readily
accessible computing education tools support children's engagement and learning of core ideas in computing
but what do i mean by that by cognitively appropriate i mean meeting the cognitive limits of users for
example surrounding literacy or problem-solving skills while still designing for the competencies that they do have as
illustrated in contemporary cognitive development literature by readily accessible i mean running on
widespread general purpose hardware like smartphones or tablets which earn 97 of
american homes rather than on specialized equipment like robots or tangible coding tools
and by core ideas and computing i mean both the key concepts of software development like sequences loops or
events and the key practices of computer science like planning decomposition
abstraction or iterative development i'll provide evidence for this argument
across two domains of computing education computational thinking and artificial intelligence
and i will show how we can leverage conversational ai to create new paradigms in computing education
how we might extend this voice-based approach into a multimodal system
how children began to think about and conceptualize this kind of voice-based ai and how we can build on top of existing
infrastructures in computing education to educate students about ai
so starting with computational thinking i'll demonstrate how we can teach computational thinking concepts to
pre-literate children through storytelling using a voice guided system called story coder
so despite a recent emphasis on computing education for all many of our youngest learners lack the advanced
literacy numeracy or fine motor skills needed to use most traditional programming environments or
computational thinking tools a number of successful solutions for young children seek to bypass these
literacy requirements but these approaches often depend on a knowledgeable teacher for students to
make meaningful progress in the case of block-based programming environments or they require expensive and
specialized technologies that are not readily available to all students in the case of tangibles or programmable robots
and although these tools support children's engagement with computing concepts they often lack scaffolding for key
practices like decomposition this design leads to bottom-up development and non-reusable
fine-grained code both of which are contrary to accepted practices in computing but why is this the case
as it stands many of the computer science education tools today are informed by piagettian psychology
which suggests that children cannot reason abstractly until they're much older around age 12.
but my own work into children's capacities for problem decomposition joins a growing body of literature in
the cognitive development space and telling another story about children's abstract reasoning skills
we leveraged a block building paradigm and we asked children to reconstruct target structures from components
and we showed that contrary to prior belief decomposition skills do begin to develop
by early elementary years we therefore aim to directly support children's engagement with decomposition
and abstraction while still introducing computing concepts like sequences and loops
so in this project i demonstrate that children can learn computational thinking concepts in a way that
simultaneously builds literacy skills by engaging with these ideas through storytelling
and further aligning with the oral traditions of storytelling it's possible to introduce these computing concepts
using a smartphone-based voice interface which allows even pre-literate children to engage with this material without
necessitating any specialized hardware finally we do so in a way that scaffolds
decomposition and abstraction while children learn computing concepts
from a curricular standpoint we pulled our computational learning goals from brennan and resnick's 2012 computational
thinking definition which was developed for elementary school learners using scratch
and from the k-12 cs framework so cross-referencing these lists we identified four key computing concepts
sequences loops events and data or variables and four key computing practices decomposition
abstraction planning and computing for self-expression
from a storytelling perspective prior work has shown that early exposure to storytelling can improve children's
reading writing listening and oracy skills later in life and specifically reading children aloud
reading stories aloud to children and explicitly teaching them story structure improves language comprehension and
reading comprehension skills later on so we aimed to support these activities as well
to also ensure that our solution was grounded in the needs of teachers and learners we engaged in needfinding
we conducted semi-structured interviews with 11 participants and two classroom observations as pictured in this photo
on the right and through this formative investigation we identified three key design objectives beyond these
curricular goals first we found a need to make tools accessible to children in terms of
literacy for children who are non-readers and financially we turn to voice interaction to support
these young pre-literate learners in expressing complex or abstract ideas and we built a system that could run on
general purpose hardware smartphones we found a need to make tools
approachable to children educators and parents who might be experiencing self-doubt and their ability to learn or
teach about computing we aim to make our solution approachable even to reticent learners by using storytelling as a really familiar domain
by which to teach these computing concepts and finally educators mentioned a need
for long-term engagement they suggested the personally meaningful projects could drive these engage this
engagement by allowing students to get invested in what they're actually working on we therefore gave children agency about
the kinds of stories that they could tell to ensure the system connects to their interests
putting this all together we built story coder a voice-based smartphone application that introduces computing
concepts to children through storytelling games story coder consists of six voice
based user flows two targeting storytelling which guide children in creating and listening to stories and
four story games that each use storytelling as a domain to learn about a specific computational concept
so child might begin by engaging with the create a story flow so in this flow the app scaffolds
decomposition and abstraction as the child generates a story plan it does so by asking about the main
character the location and the problem and the story and then it encourages the child to tell
the story with a beginning a middle and an end
let's make a story plan i'm going to ask four questions question one is the star
of your story a person or animal [Music]
animal awesome what kind of animal a dog
sounds good we'll tell a story about a dog
so once a child has created their story they can listen to it or they can play with that story to engage with key
computing concepts sequences loops events and variables through one of four computational story games
for example in word events a child can pick a word and their story to be an event which can then trigger recorded
sound effects awesome we will record a sound effect
for the word event clue you can record any kind of noise as soon as you tap on the microphone start
recording your noise [Music]
whenever we hear the word flute we'll play the sound
so every user flow underwent a design process that included wizard of oz testing prior to implementation
and iterative testing after development to further improve our system's design we then conducted an evaluation of the
system with 22 children age five to eight half of these children were female and
half were male with seven entering kindergarten and five entering each of first through third grade
children came from eight different u.s states had reading levels ranging from pre-reader to early fluency
and had no prior exposure to computer science each child participated in four
60-minute sessions over zoom on four consecutive days so on the first day we dedicated the
session to app setup and pre-assessment on the second and third day children played with the story coder app
and on the fourth and final day we completed post assessment we specifically sought to answer eight
research questions that related to our overarching objectives in the development of story comprehension
computational learning and attitudinal shifts towards computing for today i'm
just going to go over two of these in detail one related to storytelling and one related to computing
so beginning with storytelling we asked do children tell better stories with the scaffolding provided by the system
we asked children to tell three stories over the course of the study first in pre-assessment they told us a
story without any constraints which we called the free storytelling condition so we asked them tell us a story about
anything also in pre-assessment they told us a story in which we verbally provided the
same constraints that they received from the guidance in the app which we call the constrained storytelling condition
and finally children told the story during gameplay or in-app condition
so we asked if the planning activity or the constraints provided therein would help children to tell better stories
overall we scored these stories by using the index of narrative complexity which is a
13 item rubric that was designed as a progress monitoring tool so to compare a child's stories to their own former
stories and what we found is that children told significantly better stories with the
planning guidance provided by our app than they did without such guidance so we see that stories told in
pre-assessment without any planning scaffolding are on the left and we can see the increase in scores
and planned stories on the right i'll note though that this effect is specific to older children
this might be because the majority of the younger age group had yet to even start kindergarten with the beginning of formal schooling
we see a rise in related skills like planning or auditory memory so the lower
scores in that group might be as a result of this looking next computing we also ask can
children recognize the computing concepts in the new context specifically scratch animations
so for this recognition task we first explained that my friend sarah made a new game except and her game taught the
same four ideas as story coder except her game uses animations instead
of stories another child johnny played this animation game
he picked an animation to start with and then he changed it just a little bit as he was playing
so we played children up before animation and then after animation and we asked them which game had cellini
played we ran eight trials two covering each concept where one of those trials was a
near transfer example of that concept and the other one was a farther transfer example relative to the presentation of
that concept in the app and we'll report percent correct here
if a child had learned nothing we might expect that their responses would resemble the responses of a child who
was guessing they would show chance level performance which here is denoted by this dotted
blue line overall though we found that children were able to recognize the four
computing concepts both younger and older age groups performed significantly above chance on
this concept recognition task so in this work we developed story coder
and through it we showed that preliterate children can use a conversational voice interface
to effectively learn computational thinking concepts through storytelling games
story coder demonstrated the potential for voice interfaces and delivering educational content
but it also came with its own set of challenges so we continued on to build a more robust multi-modal extension of the
system which we're calling visual story coder so in this follow-up we developed a
system that supported the creation of more complex stories and also included more concrete learner engagement around
computing practices like decomposition and abstraction
story coder showed that voice interfaces can be successful in delivering instruction but voice interaction also presents
challenges to cognitive load and navigation which can prevent the creation of more complex stories
to use a voice only app a child needs to remember everything that they've already done in order to decide what to do next
and if they want to navigate elsewhere or go back it's a lot easier to do that by pressing a button than it is to
navigate by voice block based programming interfaces on
the other hand present continuous cues and reminders through a graphical interface
but these interfaces can suffer from a lack of built-in instruction which can make it hard for children to
succeed without access to educator support so we developed visual story coder a
multimodal system that blends the strengths of these approaches to overcome their respective weaknesses
this system more actively engages children with decomposition and abstraction while also supporting the
creation of more complex stories so this system is aided by flow the fish
which is an instructional voice agent you see in the top left this child has completed the planning
process she's about to start telling her story so we can watch her make her first chapter
i'm excited to hear your story about a it's about a basketball player
after a basketball court hit the check mark to get started
awesome our story will have at least three chapters a beginning a middle and an
end and to get started drag a dark green chapter block into our workspace just
like in books our chapters will hold pages pages are where we'll add words and pictures to our story we can add
pages to a chapter with a page block
great every page should have both words and pictures tap on that page to start editing
oh in the beginning we talk about the star and the location of the story can you
tell me the beginning of your story this is about it [Laughter]
awesome now let's draw a picture for this page of your story you can drag stamps of the star location and problem
into the picture for this page or you can use the toggle to switch to draw mode
thanks for telling me about the beginning of your story when you're done with the beginning tap on the smiley face on this chapter and save it by
choosing an emoji
now that your chapter is saved we can add it to your story your story is at the bottom of the screen tap the plus
button to add a chapter to the story and select the emoji for the beginning chapter
so through this interface a learner specifically engages with abstraction and decomposition by modeling their
story or modeling their program as a story and then by breaking that story down into chapters and chapters into pages
by defining chapters with emojis and then including those chapters in the main story they're engaging with
activities akin to defining functions and then calling those functions from their programs
once they've created their full story they can again engage with loops events and variables
for example they can turn the stamps that they included in their story's pictures into variables and change them
out for new pictures so this girl decided that it was obvious that her story about a basketball player
took place at a basketball court and she wanted to be more specific so she changed her location so her story took
place at a basketball center rather than at school for example
a variable is a thing that can change but we can only change one thing for another of the same type
we can make the picture stamps in your story into variables now can you draw a new picture of the
location
cool now you're using a variable in your story we have changed out the stamp anytime you used it in your story
pictures and then we can see that change manifest in her story pictures wherever she used
that location stamp so we conducted a between subject's
evaluation of the system with 24 children age six to eight half of them use visual story coder and
half of them use scratch junior which is a leading block based programming app for this age group
six first graders and six second graders participated in each of these conditions and none of these children had any prior
instruction in computer science children participated in two 60-minute
sessions over zoom on two consecutive days on the first day they independently
played with the app the experimenter wasn't allowed to provide any support or answer any questions
on the second day the child received instructions on four concepts in the app those four concepts were the same across
all children but the instruction was rooted in the project that they'd created on day one
then they had another 30 minutes to create a brand new project except this time they were allowed to ask questions
so before going further i do want to lend some context to this comparison in visual story coder children program
stories using chapter and page blocks and an agent provides just-in-time instruction
in scratch junior children program animations by controlling the motion of characters using code blocks
there's a tutorial video in the app which all children in this condition watched at the start of session 1 but
there's otherwise little built-in support through this comparison we look to
answer three key research questions related to our overarching objectives in supporting at-home learning through
built-in instruction and an emphasis on computing practices so we asked does built-in instruction
and a focus on decomposition and abstraction affect the degree of system understanding among users and the
quality of code artifacts that they produce does experimenter instruction and
question answering in session two impact the system understanding and code quality
and how engaging do children find these two systems again for today i'm just gonna go over
two of these so we'll talk about system understanding and code quality
so we looked at two quantitative metrics and two qualitative metrics to answer these questions
first we evaluate the degree of understanding of key aspects of the system scored from a rubric based on a post
session quiz we also quantified the quality of the code artifacts that children produced
based on a rubric for scoring scratch junior projects this rubric was pulled from prior work then we created a direct
mapping adaptation of that rubric to score the visual story photo projects
we collected qualitative data from experimenter observations during gameplay and from an artifact-based interview at
the end of each session in which we asked children about the projects that they'd made
so looking at our data we see an unsurprising significant effect of system understanding by session
so as you see here we see an increase in system understanding in the second session after children have had an opportunity
to familiarize themselves with the app after they've received instruction and after they've had a chance to ask
questions and i'll note that here and on all graphs in this presentation error bars are 95 confidence intervals
interestingly though we also see a significant interaction between app and session
children using scratch junior had a much larger increase in understanding from session one to session two
whereas this was not so much the case with visual story coder where the change in system understanding after
instruction was much smaller we interpret this as support for the ability of built-in instruction to teach
a child about a system a visual story coder whereas scratch jr really benefited from that instruction educator
support qualitatively participants spoke about how the instruction was important to
them and figuring out how to use the app so when asked what they did when they got stuck one eight-year-old using
storycoder said it was important for me to know to click on the fish when i didn't know what to
do of course in our app clicking on the fish would make it repeat its instructions
on the other hand children using scratch jr talked about being confused clicking about randomly when they didn't know
what to do or just ignoring the parts that they didn't understand different eight-year-old said when i was
confused with something i kind of just ignored it and did something different
based on this qualitative data we believe that built-in instruction was critical to the system understanding in
visual story coder next we look at code quality across
sessions we find that the average code quality for visual story coder is higher but not
to a statistically significant degree when aggregated across sessions but we also see a great deal of variance
and code quality scores in session one in scratch there were children who didn't touch the code blocks at all and
there were children who dragged every single code block possible into their projects just to see what they would do
our rubric was based on the presence of code blocks and projects so that contributed to a lot of variants in
scratch jr in storycoder we had multiple children who didn't get through the full user
flow of the app in the allotted 30 minutes because they spent so much time telling their stories
this means that they didn't get a chance to engage with loops events or variables which also means that these concepts
weren't present in their projects in this first session so as a follow-up we look only to
session two when students have familiarized themselves with the app and what it can do and we find that students using visual
story coder do create statistically higher quality stories
we attribute some of this difference to the app scaffolding around planning children using visual story coder talked
about the need to plan their stories whereas those using scratch jr often mentioned making up their story as they
went along when asked how they got their idea for their project one six-year-old using storyteller said
i got started by thinking who was in the book and then i was like thinking about what they would do and it was important
for me to have a plan on the other hand one seven-year-old using scratch jr said
i went to like the plus button and i saw a really pretty flower and i wanted it to be part of my story so then i thought
of that but i technically made it up as i went differences in this reported planning
behavior provide evidence for how visual story coder can support children's planning processes
so overall with visual story coder we demonstrated how multi-modal interfaces with built-in instruction
help learners better apply computational thinking practices
shifting gears now to look to the domain of ai education we first ask how young learners intuitively think about
conversational ai like the kind they interacted with in story coder
so when we were developing story coder we time and again heard stories from parents about their children's interactions with conversational ai
there was a four-year-old who when told his entire family was going on vacation asked is google coming to
and there was a three-year-old whose family had a korean rice cooker and every time the rice was ready it would say in korean the rice is ready and this
three-year-old would go running over to the rice cooker to talk to her grandma the only korean speaker in her life
so with virtual assistants everywhere we begin to question when a young child begins to interact with this kind of
technology what is it they think they're talking to and how do they extend their cognitive capacities for reasoning about other
human minds in order to reason about this kind of ai
so we know that humans have robust systems for identifying living and non-living for distinguishing between
agents and objects and for reasoning about the minds of other humans
but conversational ai falls into this unusual psychological pocket of exhibiting many of the key behaviors of
living agents and humans in particular while being distinctly non-living objects
by preschool children's speech is coherent enough for them to begin interacting with conversational ai
at this point children have a robust understanding that agents are goal directed and have internal responses to
external behavior they're also beginning to understand that agents can have knowledge separate
from themselves and beliefs that differ from ground truth which both influence this
goal-directed behavior and further prior work has shown how children extend this reasoning to
non-human agents but it remains unclear what of this intuitive psychology
might they leverage in interactions with conversational ai and how might they use these cognitive capacities to build mental models around
this kind of ai more broadly limited prior work exists in this space
but in one study children aged three to six interacted with google home for a brief period
before being asked to draw google notably before age six
some of those drawings contained a human-like feature like eyes or mouth
here we see that one child said google is a girl but she doesn't have any arms
after age six though none of those drawings contained any human-like elements
so we initially piloted a similar task and we found similar trends but the study doesn't ultimately help us
understand how children represent the mental states of these devices to reason about their behavior
so we ask how do children reason about the minds of virtual assistants
one possibility is that children reason about these devices in the same way that they'd reason about human minds before
they be begin to distinguish the nuances of these devices from the minds of people
so let's look at how children reason about the minds of people this paradigm in particular rests
heavily on something called false belief so let me first explain that as an example
this is rachel rachel brought raisins to have during snack time
rachel's in a room with two containers and rachel decides to put her raisins in the blue container
then rachel goes away now while rachel is away joe comes in
joe decides to play a trick on rachel joe takes rachel's raisins out of the blue container and moves them to the
green container and then joe goes away so now
rachel comes back in where will rachel look for her raisins the blue container or the green
container hopefully you all realize that in this scenario joe
knows that the raisins are in the green container but rachel falsely believes the raisins are in the
blue container adults would understand that these two people have separate minds with separate
information adults would answer blue container your average three-year-old though would
answer green container because three-year-olds typically fail to represent others false beliefs
this comprehension of false belief is a key marker in children's understanding of others minds that we build upon in
our study so what does the developmental trajectory of false belief understanding
look like something like this three-year-olds typically fail false
belief tasks they give responses consistent with the understanding that rachel and joe share
a mind they would say that rachel would look for her raisins in the green container
in the years following though we see a sharp increase in understanding such that children demonstrate adult
level performance on these false belief tasks by age six six year olds would give answers
consistent with the understanding that people have separate minds and they would say that rachel would
look for her raisins in the blue container so returning to our question we asked
how do children reason about the minds of virtual assistants or more specifically how do children
extend their false belief reasoning to reason about virtual assistants
so we present to children with a false belief task so here scotty and the dark blue shirt goes into
a room and tells one person that his favorite song is the itsy bitsy spider
then he goes into a different room and tells a different person that actually his favorite song is the wheels on the
bus and finally he returns to the first room and asks that first person can you
please play my favorite song our key question is what song will this person play
hopefully you all say this person will play the itsy bitsy spider the first song because that's what scotty told
this first person in this first room was his favorite song even though he later corrected that information for a
different agent your average three-year-old though would say that this person would play the wheels on the bus because of their lack
of understanding of false beliefs now imagine that scotty was talking to smart
speakers instead the interaction is the same what song would the first speaker play
the answer maybe isn't as clear but if these two devices are in the same household and connected to the same
account you might infer that the first smart speaker would actually have the updated information given to the second
smart speaker and play the second song the wheels on the bus
turns out adults understand this so here we ran the study online with 59 adults
on prolific and we plot the proportion of adults in each condition answering with each song
in our person condition in gray adults say that the person in the first room will play the itsy bitsy spider the
first song but in the a.i condition in blue
we see that adults say that the smart speaker in that first room will play the second song the wheels on the bus
a replication of the study yields the same results adult responses and the person condition
are consistent with the understanding that people have separate minds but in the ai condition responses are
consistent with the understanding that smart speakers have a shared mind or a connected back end
so we've also run 135 children age 3 to 8 through this task conducted remotely
over zoom as a reminder i've plotted adult level performance as points here on the right
again the person condition is gray and the ai condition is blue so what do children do
looking first to the person condition we see that our data follows the false belief trajectory that i previously
showed three-year-olds are answering incorrectly on this task because of their failure to reason about false
beliefs but by age six children are demonstrating adult level performance and giving responses consistent with the
understanding that people have separate minds turning to the ai condition we might
expect the curve to look something like this green curve that i've drawn on the graph
children might start in a similar place with a lack of representation of false beliefs
the curve might be bend upward as children begin to understand false belief but it should ultimately end up down at
the bottom somewhere near adult level understanding looking at our data though we see that
in the ai condition if we first look at children who do not have connected smart speakers at home
their responses again follow the false belief trajectory children in this group have not begun to
differentiate the mental states of these devices from those of people perhaps because they've not had enough
experience with these devices to start building separate mental models
but if we look to children that do have connected smart speakers at home we see that even children with extensive
experience with these devices don't give answers that anywhere resembles adult level understanding
so this is an example of ai that these children do interact with but we undoubtedly see a clear
difference in understanding between even eight-year-olds and adult-level performance
so returning once more to our research questions we find that children's reasoning about the mental states of
these devices follows in line with their reasoning about humans at least through age 8 in this false belief task
experience with connected smart speakers at home may have some impact on this understanding
but adult level understanding doesn't emerge until sometime between age 9 and 18.
therefore this work demonstrates that children's misunderstandings of ai systems
suggests a need for ai education that helps to facilitate more accurate
mental model development
which leads me to the last project that i'll discuss today an accessible system for ai education
and i do want to mention here that this next section contains work i did while working at apple
so conversational ai is just one example of the kinds of systems ai driven systems that kids might interact with
with the increasing prevalence of ai and machine learning in everyday life we see that researchers and educators
have started advocating for studying ai machine learning education as a complement to
contemporary computing education today robotics is one of the main entry
points to computing but while state-of-the-art robotics makes heavy use of ai and machine learning k-12
robotics education today centers on mechanical engineering and imperative programming
this makes robotics an ideal context for introducing ai and machine learning to students
in particular robotics is a natural fit for exploring reinforcement learning which is a type of machine learning used
in state-of-the-art robotics research but reinforcement learning also drives some of today's day-to-day ai
technologies that young children might be interacting with reinforcement learning has been less studied in the ai education space but we
also hypothesize it's conceptually easy comparatively to understand
although robotics is relatively widespread the cost of specialized hardware can be a huge barrier to access
so we also aim to create a more accessible robotics education by leveraging virtual robots that run on
general purpose hardware tablets and then bringing these robots to life using augmented reality
so in our work we built autonomous a robotics education experience for middle school students that addresses cost
barriers to wider implementation by leveraging general purpose hardware and tests our conjecture that young
learners can develop a conceptual understanding of reinforcement learning
to make sure we're all on the same page i'll go over the concept behind reinforcement learning
reinforcement learning is a machine learning training method based on rewarding desired behaviors and
penalizing undesired ones or in other words it's learning from rewards and penalties
imagine training a dog if a dog does something good you might give it a reward like a treat
it does something bad you might get a give it a penalty like scolding it over time that dog might become more or
less likely to take a similar action in a similar situation
in the context of robotics we can train a robot robot to navigate using simulations one that does something good
we can give it points when it does something bad we'll take away points
in the autonomous app students use reinforcement learning to train autonomous navigation models that
integrate with event driven code allowing the user to customize their robot's behavior
users are able to create tracks for their robots train virtual robot agents to navigate
these tracks using reinforcement learning view simulations and visualizations of
that training and combine their models with code for flexible closed-loop robotics
so for the purposes of a demo let's imagine that the student had this objective they wanted a school bus robot to
navigate autonomously around a bus route track it should stop flash its lights and load passengers at every one of the red bus
stops and it should stop unload all its passengers again flashing its lights at the yellow school bus stop at the bottom
so our user here has already recreated this bus route track in the app and they start with a partially
pre-trained robot that means that if we test this current robot on the bus route track we'll see
that it knows it should be moving forward but it's not very good at following the track yet especially on tight turns
going back we can create a track to train our robot on the target's an issue that we've identified so the square
track gives the robot practice on those tight turns so we save the track and kick off that training
training can take some time so speaking speeding it up a bit here we see that the car does get better over time
and on episode 50 it actually does pretty good so next we can bring this experience to
life and check out a simulation of that 50th episode in augmented reality
finally returning to our bus route track for another test run now that we've done some training we see that our robot does
better but we also see that it still has some training to do
once students have a working model they can switch over to the code editor which will load up the course and the robot
navigation model on the right and present users with the development environment on the left
this interface contains a function library that students can use to customize robot behavior during event
driven callbacks for example they could change the robot's color to yellow at the start of the run or flash lights and pick up a
passenger at a pickup point we evaluated this experience in
90-minute remote sessions with 15 middle school students age 11 to 14.
six of these students were female 9 were male and all of these students had prior experience with robotics or
hardware after an introductory phase students trained a robot to navigate and wrote
code to achieve that school bus objective that i showed in the demo we then concluded with about 10 minutes
of questions and feedback so we measured participants developing understanding of reinforcement learning
their engagement with the apps and their curiosity to learn more about machine learning
across several measures we found that participants developed an understanding of reinforcement learning
for example when asked what reinforcement learning is 93 percent of participants described
reinforcement learning as an agent learning from rewards penalties or experiences for future novel situations
for example one 12-year-old said about reinforcement learning it's when you have something do something and it takes
your input and it does an action and then you give it like points or not points or whatever so that knows when it
did something wrong and when it did something right so they can try to do the right thing next time
looking at participants engagement we took the seven prompts from the giggle gauge metric which is a validated
